intro: Abildgaardia hispidula subsp. senegalensis, commonly known as the Senegalese hibiscus, is a shrub native to tropical Africa. It is characterized by its rough, hairy stems and large, showy flowers that typically bloom in shades of yellow or orange. The plant produces capsule fruits containing numerous small, black seeds. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in woodland or savanna habitats. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens in warm climates.

It is commonly found in dry savannas and grasslands with well-drained soils. This subspecies thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in open habitats with moderate to high sunlight exposure. It is adapted to seasonal rainfall patterns and can tolerate drought conditions. The plant is often seen as part of the vegetation in semi-arid environments across western and central Africa.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abildgaardia hispidula subsp. senegalensis was mainly introduced to regions with arid or semi-arid climates, particularly in parts of Africa and the Middle East. It is commonly found in sandy soils and along coastal areas where it can thrive in dry conditions. This subspecies is often used for soil stabilization and erosion control due to its hardy nature.
